1548024035_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5.body:
Windows doesn't read common Linux filesystems out of the box (as far as I know.) You'll have to format it as a filesystem both can read (NTFS maybe?, FAT/32.)

The easiest thing would be to store it on an external HDD/SSD until you settle your partition scheme. 

It really depends on what you're looking to do. Mainly using Windows? Mainly Linux? What are you doing on each OS?

> [klu9](#comment_35_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs): Thanks everyone! Making a note of all these ideas. [...]

Someone made a post about using a thumb drive for ZeroNet and it thrashed it. Those, like SD cards, have a more limited read/write lifespan than SSD/HDD.

If you're going to do any investment, and you already have a spare external drive, you could simply buy a Raspberry Pi (~$50) and plug in the external drive to it and access it over the network (which will also give you a cheap solution to test out using Linux.) 

From that you could also set up a media center / torrent box so you won't have to mess with your main system. It becomes a pain to reformat, resize, etc. unless you know exactly what you're going to use your system for and it's not going to change (not to discourage you from experimenting, just a heads up!) 

If you're not doing anything serious on Linux yet, you could always just load up a Live USB and use it when you need it to play around without having to modify your system and find a distro you like. You can then mount your Windows drive and access your files without having to partition anything.

Lots of roads you can take, just depends on what you're willing to work on and what you have available :)

> [klu9](#comment_37_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs): Yeah, I think that was quantumworld who had that problem. I guess I was thinking of the SD card maybe for running an OS as an alternative to a Live USB or internal HDD install (and to save a USB port). IIRC Puppy loads into RAM and only reads/writes to the card on boot and quit. I wonder how much other live versions can do that. [...]

Running the OS from a SD probably wouldn't be an issue, as long as no programs are reading / writing to it heavily. 

"Persistence" or "Persistent Live" would probably be good search term to find one that saves to the USB.

1555194783_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEa.body:
"Social media" should be limited to self destructing time periods of shit posting.  Maybe a day, week, month? Possibility of archiving a period and restarting. 

Everything else is documentation. 

Nobody (99.99~% of the population) retains every single memory and conversation to recall on command. These get condensed into overall ideas or feelings.

They do, however, save documents or books they would like to revisit. 

Model nature, and you find the right answer.

> [shitnotworking](#comment_9_14ogJNYFcw4vvWiy79raBJorUEcJHx1BEW): So a recap? A highlight reel? [...]

Not necessarily a recap or highlight reel, just nuke it all. Although, you could implement those, or archive X time period worth of data. 

Just think about it like everyday life. You don't keep an absolute log of every thing you did in the day and every conversation you had with everyone forever. 

It becomes even more important with the concept of ZeroNet. If you're responsible for everything you share and have to store / seed it, you're going to be more apt to curate higher quality posts / content. 

The old models of centralized storage have to change form to integrate with a decentralized model.

1557408522_1NQXKFTnE1A2rWDm3ohhpUkQ3r9TR.body:
https://digbt.org/

DIGBT is the BitTorrent DHT search engine.

DHT is a protocol for searching nodes which distribute a torrent.

Torrent is a file with metadata which describes distributed content.

DIGBT is not a tracker and doesn't store any content and only collects torrent metadata (such as file names and file sizes) and a magnet link (torrent identifier). This means DIGBT is the entirely legal system.

In addition to legality, DIGBT has two important properties: unicity and decentralization. Unicity means that DIGBT is the first system of its kind and there is nothing analogues yet. Decentralization of DIGBT provides the opportunity to search in the entire "torrent" space inside and outside of trackers (except private trackers).
